data.name:  Java
content: Java is a {{high-level programming language}} widely used around the world. It was the {{first language}} I learned thoroughly and became comfortable with.
Over time, I have reached a point where I can {{code in Java confidently}}, without needing help. It is where I first understood {{object-oriented programming}}.
I have also explored {{Spring Framework}}, and right now, I am diving deeper into {{Spring with microservices}} to expand my backend skills and build {{scalable systems}}.
If I were {{Robert Blair Mayne}}, Java would be my {{SAS}}.

data.name:  Python
content: Python is a {{high-level}}, {{interpreted}}, general-purpose programming language celebrated for its {{readability}} and {{versatility}}.
I started learning it as a {{school requirement}}, never imagining it would become my main source of {{joy}} and {{curiosity}}.
I love automating {{everyday tasks}} with Python — from managing my {{Notion schedule}} to tracking {{expenses}} and setting {{reminders}}.
Just for fun, I explored {{Flask}} and {{FastAPI}} to build {{RESTful APIs}}, discovering a whole new world of creative back-end possibilities.
If I were {{Winston Churchill}}, Python would be my {{WWII}} — the {{battlefield}} where I find {{purpose}}, {{challenge}}, and {{victory}}.

data.name:  HTML
content: HTML is the {{corner stone}} of the world wide web. It is used to {{organize}} and categorize the content of a {{website}}.
I have been using HTML for over {{10 years}} and I am very familiar with it. I have used it to build websites, web apps, desktop apps and even {{mobile apps}}.
I have used HTML to build {{static}} websites, {{dynamic}} websites, {{responsive}} websites, {{multi-platform}} software, {{progressive}} web apps and {{native}} mobile apps.
I have also used HTML to build {{websites}} for {{small}} businesses, {{medium}} businesses and {{large}} businesses.
If I were {{Ross Geller}}, HTML would be my {{Rachel Green}}.

data.name:  CSS
content: CSS is the {{paint}} of the world wide web. It is used to {{style}} and {{decorate}} the content of a {{website}}.
Although I have been using CSS for as long as I have been using HTML, I am not as familiar with it.
Like many programmers, I have a {{love-hate}} relationship with CSS. I love it because it allows me to {{express}} my creativity. I hate it because it is {{inconsistent}} and {{unpredictable}}.
If I were {{Bob Ross}}, CSS would be my {{happy little accidents}}.

data.name:  JavaScript
content: JavaScript is the {{cogs}} of the world wide web. It is used to {{power}} the content of a {{website}} and make things {{interactive}}.

I have been using JavaScript for nearly {{10 years}} and I am very familiar with it. I have used it to build all kind of solutions, from {{websites}} to {{mobile apps}}, even desktop applications like {{video games}}.
There is a joke about JavaScript that goes like this: {{JavaScript}} is so {{fast}} that it can {{render}} a {{progress bar}} in {{1 second}}.
The legend says that {{Brendan Eich}} created JavaScript in {{10 days}}. That would explain why it is so {{messy}} and {{weird}}.
If I were {{Abby Peterson}}, JavaScript would be my {{chainsaw}}.

data.name:  MySQL
content: MySQL is an {{open-source}} relational database management system ({{RDBMS}}) widely used to {{store}}, {{manage}}, and {{retrieve}} data for countless applications.
I first discovered it at {{Algonquin College}}, under the guidance of an {{incredible professor}} who led me from {{simple queries}} to the elegant complexity of {{PL/SQL}}.
Designing {{relational databases}} became a way to give {{structure}} to ideas, turning abstract data into something {{tangible}}, {{efficient}}, and {{beautiful}}.
If I were {{Luffy}}, SQL would be my {{ship}}

data.name:  PostgreSQL
content:
PostgreSQL or Postgres is a {{relational database}}. It is used to {{store}} and {{retrieve}} data.
 A relational database is a type of database that {{organizes}} data into tables, which are {{structured collections}} of records or {{rows}}, each containing a set of attributes or {{columns}}.

To interact with a relational database, you need to use a {{query language}} called {{SQL}}.
SQL is a {{declarative}} language, meaning that you {{declare}} what you want to {{retrieve}} and the database {{figures out}} how to do it.
I have been using PostgreSQL for about {{1 year}} and I am still learning a lot about it. I have used it to build the backend of {{web apps}} and {{mobile apps}}.
If I were {{King George V}}, PostgreSQL would be my {{Merchant Navy}}.

data.name: 󰙨 Automated Testing
content:
Automated testing is the {{process}} of {{writing}} and {{running}} tests {{automatically}}.
It is used to {{prevent}} bugs and {{ensure}} that the software is {{working}} as {{intended}}.
There are many types of automated tests, the most common ones are {{unit tests}}, {{integration tests}} and {{end-to-end tests}}.

Unit tests are used on a {{single}} unit of code, usually a {{function}} or a {{class}}.
Integration tests are used to check the {{interaction}} between {{multiple}} units of code.
End-to-end tests are used to poke at the {{whole}} software, from the {{user interface}} to the {{database}}.

I have been using automated testing for over {{2 years}} and I am quite familiar with it.
The tools I mostly use to write tests are {{Jest}} and {{Playwright}} although when available, I like to use a language's standard testing tools.
If I were {{Leonardo da Vinci}}, automated testing would be my {{sketchbook}}.

data.name:  React (Native)
content:
React is a {{JavaScript}} framework. It is used to {{build}} user interfaces.
It is {{declarative}}, {{component-based}} and {{unidirectional}}.

React is {{declarative}} because you {{declare}} what you want to {{render}} and React {{figures out}} how to do it.
React is {{component-based}} because you {{split}} your user interface into {{small}} and {{reusable}} components.
React is {{unidirectional}} because data flows in a {{single}} direction, from the {{top}} to the {{bottom}}.

I have been using React for over {{2 years}} and I am quite familiar with it.
I have used it to build the {{user interfaces}} of {{websites}}, {{web apps}} and {{mobile apps}} ({{React Native}}).

React is a very popular framework in the industry, although it is quite {{heavy}} and {{slow}} to {{render}} compared to other frameworks like {{Svelte}} or {{Vue}} or even lower-level solutions like {{HTMX}}.
If I were {{Joe Dalton}}, React would be my {{ball and chain}}.

data.name:  Bash
content: Bash is a {{shell}}. It is used to {{interact}} with the {{operating system}}.
It's useful to {{navigate}} the {{file system}}, {{install}} and {{update}} software, {{manage}} processes, {{configure}} the {{operating system}} and {{automate}} tasks.

I have been using Bash for over {{10 years}} but, when doing more than a basic task, I usually rely on {{AI assisted programming}} to work with it as it is not a tool I often use, nor is it easy to {{maintain}}.
I have used it to {{automate}} the {{build}} and {{deployment}} of various software, as well as {{connect tools}} together like {{GitHub}} and {{Linear}}, for example.
If I were {{Cave Johnson}}, Bash would be my {{sentry turrets}}.

data.name:  GitHub Actions
content: GitHub Actions is a {{CI/CD}} tool. It is used to {{automate}} the {{build}} and {{deployment}} of software.

It's useful to {{build}} and {{deploy}} software {{automatically}} when {{pushing}} to a {{branch}} or when {{creating}} a {{pull request}}.
It can also be used to run {{scheduled}} tasks like {{backups}} or {{maintenance}} or even custom {{Bash}} scripts.

GitHub Actions is a {{very powerful}} tool that can be used to {{automate}} almost anything.
It is {{free}} for {{open source}} projects and {{cheap}} for {{private}} projects.
It is {{easy}} to {{setup}} and {{maintain}} and it is {{very well documented}}.
GitHub Actions are written in {{YAML}}, a popular {{markup language}}.

I have been using GitHub Actions for over {{2 years}} but I barely scratched the surface.
I have used it to {{build}} and {{deploy}} the {{backend}} and {{frontend}} of {{web apps}}, {{SaaS}}, {{serverless micro-services}} and {{mobile apps}}.
If I were {{Batman}}, GitHub Actions would be my {{Robin}}.

data.name: 󰸏 AWS
content: AWS or Amazon Web Services is a {{cloud computing}} platform. It is used to {{host}} and {{scale}} software as well as a plethora of other {{services}}.

I have been using AWS for over {{2 years}} but only used a few of the available services.
I have used it to {{host}} the {{backend}} and {{frontend}} of {{web apps}}, {{SaaS}}, {{serverless micro-services}} and {{mobile apps}} as well as {{store files}} and generate {{TLS certificates}} to get that sweet {{https}}.
AWS is a {{very powerful}} tool that can be used to {{host}} and {{scale}} almost anything.
If I were {{R2D2}}, AWS would be my {{tool kit}}.

data.name:  Git
content:
Git is a {{version control system}}. It is used to {{track}} and {{manage}} changes to {{files}}.
It's useful to {{collaborate}} on {{projects}} and {{keep track}} of {{changes}}.

I have been using Git for over {{10 years}} and I am very familiar with it.
I have used it to {{collaborate}} on {{projects}} with {{teams}} of {{various sizes}} as well as {{manage}} my own personal projects.
Git is a {{very powerful}} tool that can be used to {{track}} and {{manage}} almost anything, not just code!
If I were {{Hermes}}, Git would be my {{winged sandals}}.

data.name:  Linux
content:
Linux is an {{operating system}} based on {{Unix}}.
It dominates the {{server}} space but is also the basis for the {{Android}} phone operating system.

I have been using Linux for over {{10 years}} and I am quite familiar with it.
Although I've tried various flavors ({{distributions}}), I usually go back to {{Debian based}} distributions like {{Ubuntu}}, for example.

Linux is a {{go-to}} tool for me and, by far, the best development environment I've used.
It is {{free}}, {{open-source}}, {{fast}}, {{stable}}, {{secure}}, {{customizable}} and {{extremely powerful}}.
If I were {{Buzz Aldrin}}, Linux would be my {{Apollo 11}}.

data.name: 󰍘 Software Architecture
content:
Software architecture is the {{process}} of {{designing}} and {{planning}} a {{solution}} to a {{problem}}.
It is used to {{ensure}} that the solution is {{robust}}, {{scalable}} and {{maintainable}}.

There are many {{patterns}} and {{principles}} that can be used to {{design}} a solution.
Some of the popular ones are {{MVC}}, {{MVP}} and {{MVVM}} and then many patterns like the {{Observer}}, {{Factory}} or {{Singleton}} patterns, to new a few.

Software architecture is {{crucial}} in delivering {{quality software}} that is {{scalable}} and {{maintainable}}. It also helps with {{time estimation}} and {{retrospective}} on the work that was done.
If I were {{George S. Patton}}, software architecture would be my {{M4 Sherman}}.

data.name:  UX Design
content: UX, short for {{user experience}}, is where I get to express the {{imagination}} I feel I'm living in. It's not exactly the {{world I envision}}—at least not yet—but it's the closest I can get through {{design}}.

I enjoy UX design because it lets me give shape to {{thoughts}}, {{feelings}}, and {{ideas}} in ways words can't. Of course, I'm {{not a pro yet}}, but I'm learning with every {{pixel}} and every {{interaction}}.

Even when working on {{backend systems}}, I try to consider how the experience feels — like with my {{attention to flow}}, {{custom responses}}, or just subtle {{detail crafting}} that makes something feel right without needing explanation.
If I were {{Nikola Tesla}}, UX would be my way of {{daydreaming aloud}} — a blend of {{logic}} and {{aesthetic}}, always chasing that perfect experience.

data.name: 󰓌 StackOverflow
content:
StackOverflow is a famous {{website}} where you can find any {{answer}} to any technical question, as long as you are ready to swim across an {{ocean}} of smugness and judgement.
It also has a lot of variations, geared toward {{specific industries}} and niches, even ones that are not technical at all.
It is like a {{lighthouse}} in the darkest of nights and, as long as you understand what you find, an {{amazing tool}} for any programmer.
If I were {{Ash Ketchum}}, StackOverflow would be my {{Pokédex}}.

data.name: 󱚦 AI Assisted Programming
content:
AI assisted programming is the new {{cool}} kid that just arrived.
We could say it's a mix of {{Googling}} and {{hazardous pair programming}} on steroids.

The main tools I use are {{GitHub Copilot}}, {{ChatGPT}} and {{Claude}} and although I still have to study the practice much more to be really {{efficient}}, they give me a nice {{boost}} in {{productivity}}.
When coupled with certain languages like {{Go or next}}, it sometime feels like I am the copilot!
If I were {{Masterchief}}, AI assisted programming would be my {{drunk Cortana}}.

data.name: 󰢚 Human Languages
content:
I am at least as {{Human}} as Mark Zuckerberg, therefore, I speak {{Human languages}}.
I am Fluent in {{English}}, {{Hindi}} and {{Punjabi}}

data.name: 󰛦 TypeScript
content: TypeScript is {{JavaScript}} with a {{type system}} — basically JS but with extra armor.
I started using it through frameworks like {{Next.js}} and found that it helped me {{catch errors}} before they caught me.
It lets me {{write cleaner code}} and {{scale projects}} without worrying about sneaky {{runtime surprises}}.
If I were {{Iron Man}}, TypeScript would be my {{Mark L suit}}.

data.name:  Node.js
content: Node.js is {{JavaScript}} on the {{server side}}, letting me build {{fast}}, {{scalable}} backends using a language I already know from the front-end world.
I’ve used Node.js to power {{REST APIs}}, {{real-time apps}}, and {{serverless functions}}.
With Node.js, I can jump between the {{frontend}} and {{backend}} like a skilled {{parkour athlete}}.
If I were {{Ezio Auditore}}, Node.js would be my {{hidden blade}}.

data.name:  PHP
content: PHP is the {{grandparent}} of dynamic web content — not always trendy, but it gets the job done.
I’ve used PHP for {{basic websites}} and {{server-side scripts}}, especially when dealing with {{legacy systems}}.
It’s the language that still quietly {{powers}} a huge chunk of the internet.
If I were {{Indiana Jones}}, PHP would be my {{whip}}.

data.name:  PL/SQL
content: PL/SQL is Oracles {{procedural extension}} of SQL, and it’s where {{database logic}} truly comes alive.
I learned it at {{Algonquin College}}, moving from simple {{queries}} to full {{stored procedures}} and {{triggers}}.
It lets me put {{business logic}} directly into the database for {{efficiency}} and {{performance}}.
If I were {{Chef Gordon Ramsay}}, PL/SQL would be my {{signature sauce}}.

data.name:  Kotlin
content: Kotlin is a {{modern}} language for the {{JVM}} and {{Android}} development, blending the best of {{Java}} and {{new features}}.
I’ve used Kotlin for building {{Android apps}} where concise, {{null-safe}} code matters.
It’s like Java but with {{less boilerplate}} and {{more style}}.
If I were {{Bruce Wayne}}, Kotlin would be my {{Batmobile}}.

data.name:  Angular
content: Angular is a {{TypeScript-based}} framework for building {{robust, scalable}} web applications.
I know the basics — enough to {{navigate components}}, {{services}}, and {{routing}} without feeling lost.
It’s opinionated, powerful, and sometimes {{overly dramatic}} compared to lightweight frameworks.
If I were {{Sheldon Cooper}}, Angular would be my {{roommate agreement}}.

data.name: 󰚩 Machine Learning
content: Machine Learning is where {{math}}, {{data}}, and {{algorithms}} come together to make software {{learn}} from experience.
I’ve explored it mainly through {{Python}}, using libraries like {{scikit-learn}}, {{Pandas}}, and {{NumPy}}.
From {{data preprocessing}} to {{model training}}, I enjoy experimenting with how machines can spot patterns humans might miss.
If I were {{Sherlock Holmes}}, Machine Learning would be my {{Watson}}.
